qas.question: Where is the FA cup held today?

answers.text: In 2003 the FA took the decision to permanently use the new Wembley for semi-finals

qas.question: Why is it held at Webly Stadium?

answers.text: to recoup debts in financing the new stadium.

qas.question: Do the people of London agree with this action?

answers.text: the move seen as both unfair to fans of teams located far from London

qas.question: Has the game ever fail to sell out?

answers.text: the 2013 fixture between Millwall and Wigan led to the unprecedented step of placing 6,000 tickets on sale to neutral fans after the game failed to sell out.

qas.question: Do people oppose of using the new Webly Stadium?

plausible_answers.text: to recoup debts in financing the new stadium

qas.question: Why did the FA decide to not use the new Wembley in 2003?
When did the FA decide to stop using Wembley?
What percent of people were in favor of Wembley semi-finals?
What has the FA not cited as a reason to use Wembley?

plausible_answers.text: fans of teams located far from London

qas.question: Who was the move seen as fair to?

context: <a0_0>In <b6_0>2003<b6_0/> the FA took the decision to permanently use the new Wembley for semi-finals<a0_0/> <a1_0><b5_0>to recoup debts in financing the new stadium<b5_0/>.<a1_0/> This was controversial, with <a2_0>the move seen as both unfair to <b9_0>fans of teams located far from London<b9_0/><a2_0/>, as well as taking some of the prestige away from a Wembley final. In defending the move, the FA has also cited <b8_0>the extra capacity Wembley offers<b8_0/>, although <a3_0>the 2013 fixture between Millwall and Wigan led to the unprecedented step of placing 6,000 tickets on sale to neutral fans after the game failed to sell out.<a3_0/> A fan poll by The Guardian in 2013 found <a4_0><b7_0>86%<b7_0/> opposition to Wembley semi-finals.
